Your Vitamin D (25, OH D3) came back elevated or above optimal– so what does this mean? First of all, no need to worry – levels can change based on intake or use – so it’s good that you’ve picked up this slight elevation.

First of all, the majority of your Vitamin D is made in the skin through a reaction that turns a cholesterol molecule (7-deoxycholesterol) into Vitamin D3 (cholecalciferol) through the action of sunlight (or UVB light). Safe sunlight exposure therefore can increase our Vitamin D levels in the body. However, in climates that are further away from the equator, and therefore get less sunshine for more of the year, the amount of sun may not be enough to keep your vitamin D at optimal levels. Typically, sun exposure does not lead to excess vitamin D levels – but keeping an eye on it is a good idea if levels start to go too high. We also get Vitamin D from food and supplements – so exploring if you are taking in a little too much this way is a good idea.

As we absorb dietary Vitamin D through our digestive tract, if you have concerns relating to malabsorption (for e.g. Inflammatory bowel disease, chronic loose stools, Celiac disease, or other gluten / food intolerances), you’d want to ensure you keep monitoring your levels to avoid large changes.

Having high normal Vitamin D levels may be asymptomatic – meaning you may not notice any obvious symptoms. However, there are some symptoms associated with Vitamin D excess or toxicity that you may experience or want to watch for if levels continue to rise: nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, constipation, abnormal heart rhythm, weakness, frequent urination, confusion, apathy, excessive thirst, dehydration and kidney stones.

Too much vitamin D can lead to an excess or imbalance of blood calcium and phosphate levels. This can occur in a condition called hyperparathyroidism (excess parathyroid activity). If calcium levels are elevated, it can lead to calcification of various soft tissues (including the kidneys and blood vessels), formation of kidney stones, and if very off balance heart irregularities. Elevated or toxic levels of Vitamin D (usually well above 250 nmol/L) can also lead to a weakening of bones through Vitamin K2 reduction.

Vitamin 1, 25-dihydroxy Vitamin D (the active Vitamin D hormone) that is converted from 25-hydroxy Vitamin D3 (what you’ve had measured on your bloodwork) may become too high if there is extra production outside of the kidneys in other more rare conditions.

It’s important to note that as you work toward reducing & optimizing your blood levels of Vitamin D, you have the potential to improve your bone & dental strength, mental health, hormonal balance, and reduce risks for certain cancers, autoimmune and chronic diseases (like MS, Type 1 and 2 diabetes, and cardiovascular disease etc.).

As a woman potentially still in your reproductive years, it’s important to note that having sufficient vitamin D is very important in pre-conception and prenatal health. Moving your levels into the optimal range may benefit a healthier pregnancy (carrying to term, lower risk of C-section, minimizing certain health risks in pregnancy like pre-eclampsia), post-partum health (including mental well-being) as well as baby’s health in utero and longer term.
tooHigh.treatment:
Now that you’ve found out you have higher normal Vitamin D, one of the main ways to maintain or reduce your levels back into the optimal range is to reduce your intake of supplemental Vitamin D. If you eat a large amount of Vitamin D3 rich foods (like liver or cod liver oil), this would be another way that you could slightly be overdoing it (see below).

Around 90% of our Vitamin D can be produced by UVB sunshine. Even 10-15 minutes of unprotected sun (i.e. no sunscreen or clothing covering at least one part of your skin) may be enough to keep Vitamin D levels in the sufficient range. As many people work & live indoors most of the day, live in latitudes more than 34° north or south of the equator, or wear a lot of protective sun clothing or sunscreens – it may be difficult to get enough sun throughout the year to keep our Vitamin D levels optimal. And it is nearly impossible to get too much vitamin D through sun exposure. Also of note, how dark our skin pigment is can also impact how much sun is needed to create the optimal level of Vitamin D (i.e. the darker your skin, the more sun is needed to create a similar amount of vitamin D).

We do get Vitamin D3 (cholecalciferol) in food from animal sources such as:

  • fatty fish (salmon, mackerel or sardines)
  • egg yolks
  • animal liver (organic / pasture & grass fed ideally)
  • Historically, some cultures would have gotten more of these foods in their diet on a semi-regular basis to sustain their vitamin D through the winter time (eg. liver every other week at family dinners). However, if you are consuming a large amount of these foods, you may want to consider reducing your intake slightly (especially if this is the primary way your levels have come to be slightly high normal). Vitamin D2 (ergocalciferol) can also be found from food sources – but typically as a small food fortification (e.g. added to milk products) or from sun-exposed mushrooms. Typically, food sources won’t cause elevated or toxic levels of blood vitamin D as you would need to eat quite a lot of these foods on a daily basis.
  • Supplementation, used to increase our Vitamin D levels is likely the main contributor to elevated or higher normal vitamin D blood levels. Supplemental Vitamin D can come in varying forms, but the most commonand effective source is Vitamin D3 (cholecalciferol) found in capsules, liquids or products like cod liver oil. (Injectable forms of Vitamin D are available and used by health care providers in certain situations and should be monitored in order to avoid overuse or toxicity situations.)

Reducing your current Vitamin D supplement slightly to move back into the optimal ranges (retesting appropriately) may be of benefit.

  • Obesity has been shown to be associated with Vitamin D deficiency. Some researchers believe it has to do with Vitamin D being stored in fat tissues, preventing the active use of it in our bodies. Healthy weight balance may also improve your vitamin D status and how it’s being used in conjunction with other hormone systems.
  • Newer research shows that Vitamin D may be degraded (or broken down) in our bodies by the action of a receptor called Pregnane X Receptor (PXR). It can trigger (by attaching to our genes) the CYP24 enzyme to degrade stored or active forms of Vitamin D (25,(OH)D3 or 1,25 (OH)2 D3 respectively) into inactive forms. This PXR receptor, can be activated or triggered by some medications and toxicants from the environment (e.g. BPA or Pesticides). Choosing organic food can reduce your exposure to pesticides. To reduce BPA exposure and intake you can start by eating less packaged foods or food & drinks from plastic containers, and avoiding handling thermal receipts (especially if you use lotion or hand sanitizers on your hands). And while we reduce these types of toxicant exposures, we can also reduce the potential for active or usable forms of Vitamin D to be degraded – potentially improving or balancing our total blood levels.

The basic RDA for Vitamin D has been changing over the last several years. Where once thought that 400 IU/day was enough, more current recommendations look more around 1-2000 IU/day. Upwards of 10,000 IU/day has generally been considered safe – however, everyone’s needs and use of Vitamin D may differ and monitoring the right dose for you is important through regular follow-up testing by your health care provider.

Please speak with your healthcare practitioner to explore further testing and next steps.

In the immune system, Vitamin D plays a role in its modulation as well as inflammation. Vitamin D has signaling effects of inhibiting the inflammatory cascade and a suggested role in mitigating the cellular immune response (especially relating to respiratory infections). The innate immune system, which produces pro and anti-inflammatory cytokines in response to acute (respiratory) infections, can be calmed (when overreacting) and modulated as needed by Vitamin D. There is research showing its connection in autoimmune diseases such as type 1 diabetes, Multiple Sclerosis and Rheumatoid Arthritis as well as certain cancers when in deficient levels.

Vitamin D also plays a role in gut integrity. Gut health is a very important aspect to overall wellbeing and our immune functioning. Vitamin D has a role in properly functioning tight junctions, or the ‘glue sticks’ that hold the intestinal cells together (as well as gap junctions and adherens junctions that also impact gut integrity and function).

We also see Vitamin D playing a significant role in mental / emotional and cognitive health including links with depression, SAD, anxiety.

optimal.significance: You are in the optimal range within the normal range. Maintain this range across as many tests as possible and you are likely to experience good health for a long time.

tests.name: B12
tests.description: Vitamin B12 keeps our body’s nerves and blood cells healthy. Vitamin B12, also known as cobalamin, is a water-soluble vitamin involved in the metabolism of every cell of the human body. It is one of eight B vitamins.

tooHigh.significance:
Your B12 has come back NORMAL. Optimally we would see your B12 levels a tad lower but this level is certainly not within a range that would be deemed pathological or problematic - in fact, it's likely due to a well-balanced diet or supplement routine.

Vitamin B12 keeps our body’s nerves and blood cells healthy. It also helps our body make its genetic materials. B12 primarily gets absorbed from food: first, an acid made in the stomach (called hydrochloric acid) detaches B12 from a protein in our food that the B12 is attached to. Then, a protein produced by the stomach (called intrinsic factor) combines with B12 and ultimately helps our body absorb B12.

When the digestive system is inflamed, or is experiencing issues with absorption (due to a number of possible causes like SIBO, IBS or another inflammatory bowel disease), the body can have trouble taking up B12 from the digestive tract. The vegan population has also shown to be susceptible to B12 deficiency, as most food sources of the vitamin are animal-based proteins.

B12 contributes to the following parameters of health:

  • red blood cell formation
  • bone health / osteoporosis prevention
  • eye health - namely in the prevention of macular degeneration
  • symptoms of depression
  • neurological health / prevents loss of neurons
  • energy levels
  • hair, skin and nail health

B12 is directly connected to keeping our homocysteine levels within a healthy range. Homocysteine is an amino acid that the body naturally produces but when it increases to a certain level, homocysteine can cause chronic diseases like stroke, heart disease, osteoporosis and Alzheimer's, to name a few. Results from several randomized controlled trials indicate that combining vitamin B12 and folic acid supplements can decrease homocysteine levels in people with vascular disease or diabetes and in young adult women like yourself.

If you are pregnant, or hoping to become pregnant, studies have shown the importance of the maternal B12 levels as a fetus' brain and nervous system requires sufficient B12 from the mother to develop properly. Research has also indicated that B12 deficiencies can lead to some birth defects so this little vitamin has big implications for the expecting mom.

Your result means that your body is efficiently absorbing B12 from your food and/or supplements. Keep up the good work!
tooHigh.treatment:
In order to keep your B12 levels in a healthy range, it's important to:

  1. Continue with a balanced diet that includes sources of B12: animal-based protein, fortified nut milks, nori seaweed or organic tempeh.

  1. Consider the frequency and/or dose of your current B12 supplement, if you are already taking one, as this may help you maintain healthy levels of B12. If your healthcare practitioner assesses that you may be experiencing issues with absorbing vitamin B12 from food sources, then oral supplements or injections may help. There are two main forms of B12: methylcobalamine and cyanocobalamine so make sure to speak with your healthcare provider to decide which one is best suited for you and your health picture. Not taking the appropriate form of B12 can sometimes lead to a slight excess, especially if underlying absorption is an issue.

*If you are a vegan (meaning you don't eat any animal products, including meat, milk, cheese, and eggs) or are a vegetarian, you need to speak with your healthcare practitioner to ensure you are getting enough B12 in your diet.

tooLow.significance:
Your B12 has come back in the NORMAL range! Optimally, we would like to see your B12 levels a bit higher - B12 is a water-soluble vitamin which means your body will urinate it out daily. As you will come to find out, B12 plays a role in so many processes in the body - so keeping B12 in that sweet spot has been shown to be incredibly key for overall health.

Research has also indicated that B12 deficiencies can lead to some birth defects so this little vitamin has big implications for the expecting mom.

High vitamin B12 that has not been caused by a mis-timed test (i.e., a test that is taken right after you have taken B12) may be caused an underlying illness - an overworked liver, for example, may release the vitamin out from its storage into the blood. However, this is uncommon, especially at this level.
tooHigh.treatment:
If you are taking B12, you may want to stop until your B12 falls into a more optimal range. Because B12 is water soluble (ie: gets urinated out daily), this shouldn't take long - if you haven't been regularly taking B12, it is best to speak with your healthcare practitioner to explore other possible causes of this elevated result.

*Research has shown that elevated B12 levels due to excessive B12 supplementation does not appear to cause adverse effects when taken at 1000mcg/day for 5 years.

tooLow.significance:
Your B12 has come back BELOW normal - it maybe that either you are not taking enough B12 or your body is not absorbing the B12 that you are eating in your food or taking supplementally. Whatever the cause there may be easy ways to boost your B12.

Research has also indicated that B12 deficiencies can lead to some birth defects so this little vitamin has big implications for the expecting mom.

During and after a menstrual cycle, women's bodies have to create new red blood cells. B12, folic acid and iron are important in this process. These nutrients are important for women who experience heavy periods.

Some symptoms that may indicate a B12 deficiency:

  • otherwise unexplained weakness or fatigue
  • sensation of pins & needles
  • dizziness
  • mood changes (more prone to depression)
  • lack of focus and poor memory
  • pale skin

Your result means that your body may need some support in either absorbing B12 or in maintaining healthy levels.

Chronically low B12 levels may indicate an underlying condition such as:

  • megaloblastic anemia: the red blood cells produced in the bone marrow are big and fragile, and unable to pass from the bone marrow into circulation which means your red blood cell count goes down which = less oxygen circulation. This may present with extreme fatigue.

OR certain medications:

  • Proton Pump Inhibitors and H2 Receptor Antagonists - are drugs that are prescribed to treat GERD, acid reflux and peptic ulcer disease, can interfere with vitamin B12 absorption from food by slowing down gastric acid release in the stomach
  • Metformin - a hypoglycemic agent used to treat type II diabetes, can reduce the absorption of B12, possibly through changing the speed of food traveling through the intestines, increasing bacterial overgrowth, or causing alterations in the calcium-dependent uptake by ileal cells of the vitamin B12-intrinsic factor complex.
tooLow.treatment:
In order to increase your B12 levels, it may be indicated to:

  1. Work on a balanced diet that includes good sources of B12: animal-based protein, fortified nut milks, nori seaweed or organic tempeh.

  1. Consider starting a B12 supplement. If you are already doing so, you may need to adjust your dose, the form or the delivery of the vitamin itself. If your healthcare practitioner assesses that you may be experiencing issues with absorbing vitamin B12 from food sources, then intramuscular injections may be indicated. There are two main forms of B12: methylcobalamine and cyanocobalamine so make sure to speak with your healthcare provider to decide which one is best suited for you and your health picture.

*If you are a vegan (meaning you don't eat any animal products, including meat, milk, cheese, and eggs) or are a vegetarian, you need to speak with your healthcare practitioner to ensure you are getting enough B12 in your diet.

Some example of B12-rich foods:

  • organ meats
  • clams
  • sardines
  • grass-fed beef
  • eggs

Final note for those pregnant or trying to conceive:

Women who had a vitamin B12 deficiency during their pregnancy can inadvertently cause type 2 diabetes in their infants. Mothers who had deficient vitamin B12 had increasd BMIs. Such mothers gave birth to babies who had higher resistance for insulin which is the major risk factor in developing type 2 diabetes. Researchers concluded that women who have lower vitamin B12 levels during pregnancy can lead to birthing babies with an increased risk of metabolic syndrome such as type 2- diabetes.

B12 primarily gets absorbed from food: first, an acid made in the stomach (called hydrochloric acid) detaches B12 from a protein in our food that the B12 is attached to. Then, a protein produced by the stomach (called intrinsic factor) combines with B12 and ultimately helps our body absorb B12.

When the digestive system is inflamed, or is experiencing issues with absorption (due to a number of possible causes like SIBO, IBS or another inflammatory bowel disease), the body can have trouble taking up B12 from the digestive tract. The vegan population has also shown to be susceptible to B12 deficiency, as most food sources of the vitamin are animal-based proteins.

B12 contributes to the following parameters of health:

  • red blood cell formation
  • bone health / osteoporosis prevention
  • eye health - namely in the prevention of macular degeneration
  • symptoms of depression
  • neurological health / prevents loss of neurons
  • energy levels
  • hair, skin and nail health

B12 is directly connected to keeping our homocysteine levels within a healthy range. Homocysteine is an amino acid that the body naturally produces but when it increases to a certain level, homocysteine can cause chronic diseases like stroke, heart disease, osteoporosis and Alzheimer's, to name a few. Results from several randomized controlled trials indicate that combining vitamin B12 and folic acid supplements can decrease homocysteine levels in people with vascular disease or diabetes and in young adult women like yourself.

Some symptoms that may indicate a B12 deficiency:

  • otherwise unexplained weakness or fatigue
  • sensation of pins & needles
  • dizziness
  • mood changes (more prone to depression)
  • lack of focus and poor memory
  • pale skin

There is some evidence to support a positive correlation between healthy B12 levels and both sperm count and concentration so can be a wonderful addition to any male fertility protocol.

Your result means that your body may need some support in either absorbing B12 or in maintaining healthy levels.
tooLow.treatment:
In order to keep your B12 levels in a healthy range, it's important to:

  1. Continue with a balanced diet that includes sources of B12: animal-based protein, fortified nut milks, nori seaweed or organic tempeh.

  1. Consider continuing with a B12 supplement, if you are already doing so as this may help you maintain healthy levels of B12. If your healthcare practitioner decides that you may be experiencing issues with absorbing vitamin B12 from food sources, then oral supplements or injections may help. There are two main forms of B12: methylcobalamine and cyanocobalamine so make sure to speak with your healthcare provider to decide which one is best suited for you and your health picture.

*If you are a vegan (meaning you don't eat any animal products, including meat, milk, cheese, and eggs) or are a vegetarian, you need to speak with your healthcare practitioner to ensure you are getting enough B12 in your diet.

Some example of B12-rich foods:

  • organ meats
  • clams
  • sardines
  • grass-fed beef
  • eggs

tooHigh.significance:
Your B12 level has come back HIGH. What does this mean? Perhaps you have recently taken a large dose of a B12 supplement - doing so too soon before a blood test may cause a high B12 reading.

Vitamin B12 keeps our body’s nerves and blood cells healthy. It also helps our body make its genetic materials. B12 primarily gets absorbed from food: first, an acid made in the stomach (called hydrochloric acid) detaches B12 from a protein in our food that the B12 is attached to. Then, a protein produced by the stomach (called intrinsic factor) combines with B12 and ultimately helps our body absorb B12.

When the digestive system is inflamed, or is experiencing issues with absorption (due to a number of possible causes like SIBO, IBS or another inflammatory bowel disease), the body can have trouble taking up B12 from the digestive tract. The vegan population has also shown to be susceptible to B12 deficiency, as most food sources of the vitamin are animal-based proteins.

B12 contributes to the following parameters of health:

  • red blood cell formation
  • bone health / osteoporosis prevention
  • eye health - namely in the prevention of macular degeneration
  • symptoms of depression
  • neurological health / prevents loss of neurons
  • energy levels
  • hair, skin and nail health

B12 is directly connected to keeping our homocysteine levels within a healthy range. Homocysteine is an amino acid that the body naturally produces but when it increases to a certain level, homocysteine can cause chronic diseases like stroke, heart disease, osteoporosis and Alzheimer's, to name a few. Results from several randomized controlled trials indicate that combining vitamin B12 and folic acid supplements can decrease homocysteine levels in people with vascular disease or diabetes and in young adult women like yourself.

There is some evidence to support a positive correlation between healthy B12 levels and both sperm count and concentration so can be a wonderful addition to any male fertility protocol.

High vitamin B12 that has not been caused by a mis-timed test (i.e., a test that is taken right after you have taken B12) may be caused an underlying illness - an overworked liver, for example, may release the vitamin out from its storage into the blood.

Other possible causes of a high B12 level in the absence of supplementation include alcoholism, undiagnosed diabetes and more uncommonly, some cancers of the blood.
tooHigh.treatment:
If you are taking B12, you may want to stop until your B12 falls into a more optimal range. Because B12 is water soluble (ie: gets urinated out daily), this shouldn't take long - if you haven't been regularly taking B12, it is best to speak with your healthcare practitioner to explore other possible causes of this elevated result.

*Research has shown that elevated B12 levels due to excessive B12 supplementation does not appear to cause adverse effects when taken at 1000mcg/day for 5 years.

However, a high B12 reading is always worth investigating so it is best to speak with your healthcare provider.

Chronically low B12 levels may indicate an underlying condition such as:

  • megaloblastic anemia: the red blood cells produced in the bone marrow are big and fragile, and unable to pass from the bone marrow into circulation which means your red blood cell count goes down which = less oxygen circulation. This may present with extreme faigue.

  • Proton Pump Inhibitors and H2 Receptor Antagonists - are drugs that are prescribed to treat GERD, acid reflux and peptic ulcer disease, can interfere with vitamin B12 absorption from food by slowing down gastric acid release in the stomach

  1. Work on a balanced diet that includes good sources of B12: animal-based protein, fortified nut milks, nori seaweed or organic tempeh.

  1. Consider starting a B12 supplement. If you are already doing so, you may need to adjust your dose, the form or the delivery of the vitamin itself. If your healthcare practitioner assesses that you may be experiencing issues with absorbing vitamin B12 from food sources, then intramuscular injections may be indicated. There are two main forms of B12: methylcobalamine and cyanocobalamine so make sure to speak with your healthcare provider to decide which one is best suited for you and your health picture.

*If you are a vegan (meaning you don't eat any animal products, including meat, milk, cheese, and eggs) or are a vegetarian, you need to speak with your healthcare practitioner to ensure you are getting enough B12 in your diet.

  • sardines
  • grass-fed beef
  • eggs

B12 primarily gets absorbed from food: first, an acid made in the stomach (called hydrochloric acid) detaches B12 from a protein in our food that the B12 is attached to. Then, a protein produced by the stomach (called intrinsic factor) combines with B12 and ultimately helps our body absorb B12.

When the digestive system is inflamed, or is experiencing issues with absorption (due to a number of possible causes like SIBO, IBS or another inflammatory bowel disease), the body can have trouble taking up B12 from the digestive tract. The vegan population has also shown to be susceptible to B12 deficiency, as most food sources of the vitamin are animal-based proteins.

B12 contributes to the following parameters of health:

  • red blood cell formation
  • bone health / osteoporosis prevention
  • eye health - namely in the prevention of macular degeneration
  • symptoms of depression
  • neurological health / prevents loss of neurons
  • energy levels
  • hair, skin and nail health

B12 is directly connected to keeping our homocysteine levels within a healthy range. Homocysteine is an amino acid that the body naturally produces but when it increases to a certain level, homocysteine can cause chronic diseases like stroke, heart disease, osteoporosis and Alzheimer's, to name a few. Results from several randomized controlled trials indicate that combining vitamin B12 and folic acid supplements can decrease homocysteine levels in people with vascular disease or diabetes.

Your result means that your body is efficiently absorbing B12 from your food and/or supplements. Keep up the good work!
optimal.treatment:
In order to maintain this optimal B12 level, it's important to:

  1. Continue with a balanced diet that includes sources of B12- animal-based protein, fortified nut milks, nori seaweed or organic tempeh.

  1. Consider continuing with a B12 supplement, if you are already doing so as this may help you maintain healthy levels of B12. If your healthcare practitioner decides that you may be experiencing issues with absorbing vitamin B12 from food sources, then oral supplements or injections may help. There are two main forms of B12: methylcobalamine and cyanocobalamine so make sure to speak with your healthcare provider to decide which one is best suited for you and your health picture.

*If you are a vegan (meaning you don't eat any animal products, including meat, milk, cheese, and eggs) or are a vegetarian, you need to speak with your healthcare practitioner to ensure you are getting enough B12 in your diet.

optimal.significance:
You are in the optimal range within the normal range. Maintain this range across as many tests as possible and you are likely to experience good health for a long time.

Vitamin B12 keeps our body’s nerves and blood cells healthy. It also helps our body make its genetic materials. B12 primarily gets absorbed from food: first, an acid made in the stomach (called hydrochloric acid) which detaches B12 from a protein in our food that the B12 is attached to. Then, a protein produced by the stomach (called intrinsic factor) combines with B12 and ultimately helps our body absorb B12.
optimal.treatment: Having a balanced diet that includes sources of B-12 or taking supplements may help you maintain healthy B12 levels. If your healthcare practitioner decides that you may be experiencing issues with absorbing vitamin B-12 from food sources, then oral supplements or injections may help. If you are a vegan (meaning you don't eat any animal products, including meat, milk, cheese, and eggs) or are a vegetarian, you need to speak with your healthcare practitioner to ensure you are getting enough B12 in your diet.

tests.name: Total Cholesterol
tests.description: Total cholesterol is the total amount of cholesterol in your blood. Your total cholesterol includes low-density lipoprotein (LDL, or “bad”) cholesterol and high-density lipoprotein (HDL, or “good”) cholesterol. Cholesterol is a waxy, fat-like substance found in every cell in your body.

optimal.significance:
Congratulations! Your result has come back OPTIMAL!.

Cholesterol is a compound that is made primarily in your liver, but also in your intestines and many other body tissues. It is used in your body as a building block for other important substances like vitamin D, steroid hormones, and bile acids.

A normal cholesterol level is responsible for:

  • Maintaining cell membrane integrity and fluidity for every cell in your body. If cholesterol levels increase, cell membranes become more stiff and the flow of water and minerals like calcium, magnesium, sodium and potassium into and out of the cell is disrupted.
  • Cholesterol is also your body's building block to make bile acids. These are important for digestion and absorption of dietary fats, and the fat-soluble vitamins A, D, E, and K. Bile acids also regulate energy and help to maintain blood sugar balance.

Given your body's necessity for cholesterol, your liver and intestines work together to ensure a consistent, stable supply of it.

The excellent news is that your cholesterol level is optimal. Maintaining this optimal cholesterol level reduces your risk for cardiovascular diseases like heart attacks and stroke, as well as reducing your risk for gallstones.

If your cholesterol has changed, it has likely improved - and even though it is currently optimal, it is recommended to have your cholesterol checked regularly (every 2-3 years).
optimal.treatment:
You can help to keep your cholesterol at this ideal level by:

  • Eating a healthy, whole foods, high fiber diet. Reducing dietary cholesterol and fats usually has little to no impact on total cholesterol readings - but by limiting foods high in carbohydrates (refined sugars, starches and hydrogenated fats such as fried foods, margarine, coffee creamers, shortening etc) you can positively impact your cholesterol and therefore cardiovascular health.
  • Exercising regularly - 3-4 times/week.
  • Managing your stress by using methods like yoga, meditation and journaling
  • Cut down on / eliminate detrimental lifestyle habits such as smoking, excessive drinking or recreational drugs.

tooHigh.significance:
Cholesterol is a compound that is made primarily in your liver, but also in your intestines and many other body tissues. It is used in your body as a building block for other important substances like vitamin D, steroid hormones, and bile acids.

At this level, your cholesterol level is above optimal. Generally, there is not a particular cause for concern with this result. However, we would prefer to prevent it from rising higher.

Maintaining an optimal cholesterol level reduces your risk for cardiovascular diseases like heart attacks and stroke, as well as reducing your risk for gallstones.

A normal cholesterol level is responsible for:

  1. Maintaining cell membrane integrity and fluidity for every cell in your body. If cholesterol levels increase, cell membranes become more stiff and the flow of water and minerals like calcium, magnesium, sodium and potassium into and out of the cell is disrupted.
  2. Cholesterol is also your body's building block to make bile acids. These are important for digestion and absorption of dietary fats, and the fat-soluble vitamins A, D, E, and K. Bile acids also regulate energy and help to maintain blood sugar balance.

Given your body's necessity for cholesterol, your liver and intestines work together to ensure a consistent, stable supply of it.

You may have no warning signs if your cholesterol slips from the above optimal range into the high range. It is recommended to have your cholesterol checked regularly (every 2-3 years) as you may have no other way of knowing that it is high. If you want to be proactive about your cholesterol, there are some strategies that you can implement to make your level more optimal.

When total cholesterol levels are high, further tests to determine your cardiovascular disease risk may be helpful. These include:

  • HDL cholesterol
  • LDL cholesterol
  • VLDL cholesterol
  • triglycerides
  • HbA1C
  • fasting insulin
  • hsCRP
  • apo-lipoprotein B
  • apo-lipoprotein A1
  • lipoprotein (a)
  • fasting homocysteine
  • TSH (thyroid-stimulating hormone)
tooHigh.treatment:
Dietary & lifestyle modifications have been shown to be the best approach to achieving and maintaining healthy cholesterol levels. In some cases, medication may be necessary but even in that case, it may be helpful to implement the following:

  1. Beta sitosterols: these are plant sterol compounds. They are similar in structure to your own cholesterol. They work by decreasing the intestinal absorption of cholesterol. Studies have shown a significant decrease in blood cholesterol in subjects who were given beta sitosterols.

2. Reduce your intake of carbs and sugar. Although self-explanatory, the complete elimination of carbohydrates may not be indicated and in some cases, even safe for you. It is best to speak with your healthcare practitioner to learn more.

3. Consume a more whole foods, high fiber diet. This helps to lower your intake of foods that increase insulin. Insulin may cause increased cholesterol production in your liver.

4. Regular exercise also reduces insulin which may prevent excessive liver production of cholesterol.

5. Fish oil has been shown to lower bad cholesterol (LDL). The type and dose will need to be discussed with your healthcare practitioner.

6. Vitamin B3 or Niacin has been known to help lower cholesterol and may help prevent heart disease.

7. Cut down on / eliminate detrimental lifestyle habits such as smoking, excessive drinking or recreational drugs.

tooLow.significance:
Cholesterol is a compound that is made primarily in your liver, but also in your intestines and many other body tissues. It is used in your body as a building block for other important substances like vitamin D, steroid hormones, and bile acids.

At this level, your cholesterol level is below normal. While the greater risk generally lies in having high cholesterol, suboptimal levels may compromise your ability to make important compounds like vitamin D and bile acids.

What Does Cholesterol Do?

  1. A normal cholesterol level is responsible for maintaining cell membrane integrity and fluidity for every cell in your body. If cholesterol levels increase, cell membranes become more stiff and the flow of water and minerals like calcium, magnesium, sodium and potassium into and out of the cell is disrupted.
  2. Cholesterol is also your body's building block to make bile acids. These are important for digestion and absorption of dietary fats, and the fat-soluble vitamins A, D, E, and K. Bile acids also regulate energy and help to maintain blood sugar balance.

Given your body's necessity for cholesterol, your liver and intestines work together to ensure a consistent, stable supply of it.

Very low cholesterol has been associated with violent, aggressive, and impulsive behaviour. It has also been associated with bleeding within the tissue of the brain (primary intracerebral hemorrhage), which is only usually a risk factor in older adults. Since your liver is a source of cholesterol, severe liver disease such as hepatitis and cirrhosis may cause low cholesterol levels.

If your total cholesterol level is low, tests for ALT, AST, GGT, total bilirubin, serum albumin, HDL cholesterol, and LDL cholesterol may help determine why your cholesterol is too low.
tooLow.treatment:
Just in case you were wondering if the best way to increase your cholesterol level is low is to go out and eat lots of burgers and pizza to increase it, this is absolutely not the answer!

There are a number of possible reasons for a low cholesterol level:

  1. Cholesterol-lowering medication: always discuss adjustments to your medication with the prescribing doctor.
  2. Your good cholesterol (HDL) is too low: we know that exercise helps to boost HDL. Adding regular physical activity may help to bring your HDL and total cholesterol up.

3. Low fat diet: this fad diet is largely without merit, especially when it includes the removal of good fats, such as fish, nuts, seeds, avocados etc. Minimizing fats such as fried, processed & packaged foods, along with highly processed oils such as canola, grapeseed and safflower is generally a good idea. Especially when your cholesterol is low, making sure to include healthy fat foods is important.

tooHigh.significance:
Cholesterol is a compound that is made primarily in your liver, but also in your intestines and many other body tissues. It is used in your body as a building block for other important substances like vitamin D, steroid hormones, and bile acids.

At this level, your cholesterol level is HIGH. We would prefer to prevent it from rising higher and therefore will need to take some action.

Maintaining an optimal cholesterol level reduces your risk for cardiovascular diseases like heart attacks and stroke, as well as reducing your risk for gallstones.

A normal cholesterol level is responsible for:

  1. Maintaining cell membrane integrity and fluidity for every cell in your body. If cholesterol levels increase, cell membranes become more stiff and the flow of water and minerals like calcium, magnesium, sodium and potassium into and out of the cell is disrupted.
  2. Cholesterol is also your body's building block to make bile acids. These are important for digestion and absorption of dietary fats, and the fat-soluble vitamins A, D, E, and K. Bile acids also regulate energy and help to maintain blood sugar balance.

Given your body's necessity for cholesterol, your liver and intestines work together to ensure a consistent, stable supply of it.

You may have no warning signs that your cholesterol has slipped from the above optimal range into the high range. It is recommended to have your cholesterol checked regularly (every 2-3 years) as you may have no other way of knowing that it is high. If you want to be proactive about your cholesterol, there are some strategies that you can implement to make your level more optimal.

At this level, your cholesterol level is high. While high cholesterol in your blood increases your risk for cardiovascular diseases like heart attacks and stroke, as well as increasing your risk for gallstones, it doesn't mean that you will have to suffer these consequences. You may not experience any symptoms of high cholesterol. Alternatively, you may experience the symptoms of the conditions that are associated with high cholesterol such gallstones. The symptoms of gallstones include:

  • pain in the right upper abdomen, particularly after consuming a fatty meal - the pain may radiate to the right shoulder blade
  • inability to tolerate greasy foods
  • high blood pressure or hypertension may also be a sign that cholesterol should be checked

In some extreme cases, a heart attack or stroke may be the first sign that someone has high cholesterol. For this reason, it is recommended to have your cholesterol checked regularly (every 2-3 years) as you may have no other way of knowing that it is high; knowledge is power. Now that you know that your cholesterol is high, you can take measures to bring it down.

When total cholesterol levels are high, further tests to determine your cardiovascular disease risk may be helpful. These include:

  • HDL cholesterol
  • LDL cholesterol
  • VLDL cholesterol
  • triglycerides
  • HbA1C
  • fasting insulin
  • hsCRP
  • apo-lipoprotein B
  • apo-lipoprotein A1
  • lipoprotein (a)
  • fasting homocysteine
  • TSH (thyroid-stimulating hormone)

4. Regular exercise also reduces insulin which may prevent excessive liver production of cholesterol.

5. Fish oil has been shown to lower bad cholesterol (LDL). The type and dose will need to be discussed with your healthcare practitioner.

6. Vitamin B3 or Niacin has been known to help lower cholesterol and may help prevent heart disease.

7. Cut down on / eliminate detrimental lifestyle habits such as smoking, excessive drinking or recreational drugs.

Please speak with your healthcare practitioner.

  2. Cholesterol is also your body's building block to make bile acids. These are important for digestion and absorption of dietary fats, and the fat-soluble vitamins A, D, E, and K. Bile acids also regulate energy and help to maintain blood sugar balance.

  1. Cholesterol-lowering medication: always discuss adjustments to your medication with the prescribing doctor.
  2. Your good cholesterol (HDL) is too low: we know that exercise helps to boost HDL. Adding regular physical activity may help to bring your HDL and total cholesterol up.

3. Low fat diet: this fad diet is largely without merit, especially when it includes the removal of good fats, such as fish, nuts, seeds, avocados etc. Minimizing fats such as fried, processed & packaged foods, along with highly processed oils such as canola, grapeseed and safflower is generally a good idea. Especially when your cholesterol is low, making sure to include healthy fat foods is important.

Since a significant amount of your cholesterol is produced in your liver and intestines, measures to improve the health of these organs may help - herbs and vitamins such as NAC (n-acetyl-choline), B vitamins, dandelion root and milk thistle have shown to be effective in supporting liver health.

optimal.significance:
Congratulations! Your result has come back in the OPTIMAL range!

Cholesterol is a compound that is made primarily in your liver, but also in your intestines and many other body tissues. It is used in your body as a building block for other important substances like vitamin D, steroid hormones, and bile acids.

A normal cholesterol level is responsible for:

  • Maintaining cell membrane integrity and fluidity for every cell in your body. If cholesterol levels increase, cell membranes become more stiff and the flow of water and minerals like calcium, magnesium, sodium and potassium into and out of the cell is disrupted.
  • Cholesterol is also your body's building block to make bile acids. These are important for digestion and absorption of dietary fats, and the fat-soluble vitamins A, D, E, and K. Bile acids also regulate energy and help to maintain blood sugar balance.

Given your body's necessity for cholesterol, your liver and intestines work together to ensure a consistent, stable supply of it.

The excellent news is that your cholesterol level is optimal. Maintaining this optimal cholesterol level reduces your risk for cardiovascular diseases like heart attacks and stroke, as well as reducing your risk for gallstones.

Moreover, maintaining healthy cholesterol levels has been shown to improve fertility health, for both women and men - however, it appears to be slightly more impactful on the ability to conceive when a woman's cholesterol is elevated. Not only that, but cardiovascular disease is a concern for women of all ages - even more reason to start being mindful of your cholesterol, even before starting to attempt to conceive.

If your cholesterol has changed, it has likely improved - and even though it is currently optimal, it is recommended to have your cholesterol checked regularly (every 2-3 years).
optimal.treatment:
You can help to keep your cholesterol at this ideal level by:

  • Eating a healthy, whole foods, high fiber diet.   • Exercising regularly - 3-4 times/week.
  • Managing your stress by using methods like yoga, meditation and journaling
  • Cut down on / eliminate detrimental lifestyle habits such as smoking, excessive drinking or recreational drugs.

  2. Cholesterol is also your body's building block to make bile acids. These are important for digestion and absorption of dietary fats, and the fat-soluble vitamins A, D, E, and K. Bile acids also regulate energy and help to maintain blood sugar balance.

Given your body's necessity for cholesterol, your liver and intestines work together to ensure a consistent, stable supply of it.

Very low cholesterol has been associated with violent, aggressive, and impulsive behaviour. It has also been associated with bleeding within the tissue of the brain (primary intracerebral hemorrhage), which is only usually a risk factor in older adults. Since your liver is a source of cholesterol, severe liver disease such as hepatitis and cirrhosis may cause low cholesterol levels.

If your total cholesterol level is low, tests for ALT, AST, GGT, total bilirubin, serum albumin, HDL cholesterol, and LDL cholesterol may help determine why your cholesterol is too low.
tooLow.treatment:
Just in case you were wondering if the best way to increase your cholesterol level is low is to go out and eat lots of burgers and pizza to increase it, this is absolutely not the answer!

There are a number of possible reasons for a low cholesterol level:

  1. Cholesterol-lowering medication: always discuss adjustments to your medication with the prescribing doctor.
  2. Your good cholesterol (HDL) is too low: we know that exercise helps to boost HDL. Adding regular physical activity may help to bring your HDL and total cholesterol up.
  3. Low fat diet: this fad diet is largely without merit, especially when it includes the removal of good fats, such as fish, nuts, seeds, avocados etc. Minimizing fats such as fried, processed & packaged foods, along with highly processed oils such as canola, grapeseed and safflower is generally a good idea. Especially when your cholesterol is low, making sure to include healthy fat foods is important.

tooHigh.significance:
Cholesterol is a compound that is made primarily in your liver, but also in your intestines and many other body tissues. It is used in your body as a building block for other important substances like vitamin D, steroid hormones, and bile acids.

At this level, your cholesterol level is HIGH. We would prefer to prevent it from rising higher and therefore will need to take some action.

Maintaining an optimal cholesterol level reduces your risk for cardiovascular diseases like heart attacks and stroke, as well as reducing your risk for gallstones.

A normal cholesterol level is responsible for:

  1. Maintaining cell membrane integrity and fluidity for every cell in your body. If cholesterol levels increase, cell membranes become more stiff and the flow of water and minerals like calcium, magnesium, sodium and potassium into and out of the cell is disrupted.
  2. Cholesterol is also your body's building block to make bile acids. These are important for digestion and absorption of dietary fats, and the fat-soluble vitamins A, D, E, and K. Bile acids also regulate energy and help to maintain blood sugar balance.

Given your body's necessity for cholesterol, your liver and intestines work together to ensure a consistent, stable supply of it.

You may have no warning signs that your cholesterol has slipped from the above optimal range into the high range. It is recommended to have your cholesterol checked regularly (every 2-3 years) as you may have no other way of knowing that it is high. If you want to be proactive about your cholesterol, there are some strategies that you can implement to make your level more optimal.

At this level, your cholesterol level is high. While high cholesterol in your blood increases your risk for cardiovascular diseases like heart attacks and stroke, as well as increasing your risk for gallstones, it doesn't mean that you will have to suffer these consequences. You may not experience any symptoms of high cholesterol. Alternatively, you may experience the symptoms of the conditions that are associated with high cholesterol such gallstones. The symptoms of gallstones include:

  • pain in the right upper abdomen, particularly after consuming a fatty meal - the pain may radiate to the right shoulder blade
  • inability to tolerate greasy foods
  • high blood pressure or hypertension may also be a sign that cholesterol should be checked

Moreover, maintaining healthy cholesterol levels has been shown to improve fertility health, for both women and men - however, it appears to be slightly more impactful on the ability to conceive when a woman's cholesterol is elevated. Not only that, but cardiovascular disease is a concern for women of all ages - even more reason to start being mindful of your cholesterol, even before starting to attempt to conceive.
tooHigh.treatment:
Dietary & lifestyle modifications have been shown to be the best approach to achieving and maintaining healthy cholesterol levels. In some cases, medication may be necessary but even in that case, it may be helpful to implement the following:

  1. Beta sitosterols: these are plant sterol compounds. They are similar in structure to your own cholesterol. They work by decreasing the intestinal absorption of cholesterol. Studies have shown a significant decrease in blood cholesterol in subjects who were given beta sitosterols.

2. Reduce your intake of carbs and sugar. Although self-explanatory, the complete elimination of carbohydrates may not be indicated and in some cases, even safe for you. It is best to speak with your healthcare practitioner to learn more.

3. Consume a more whole foods, high fiber diet. This helps to lower your intake of foods that increase insulin. Insulin may cause increased cholesterol production in your liver.

4. Regular exercise also reduces insulin which may prevent excessive liver production of cholesterol.

5. Fish oil has been shown to lower bad cholesterol (LDL). The type and dose will need to be discussed with your healthcare practitioner.

6. Vitamin B3 or Niacin has been known to help lower cholesterol and may help prevent heart disease.

7. Cut down on / eliminate detrimental lifestyle habits such as smoking, excessive drinking or recreational drugs.

Please speak with your healthcare practitioner.

optimal.significance:
Congratulations! Your result has come back in the OPTIMAL range!

Cholesterol is a compound that is made primarily in your liver, but also in your intestines and many other body tissues. It is used in your body as a building block for other important substances like vitamin D, steroid hormones, and bile acids.

A normal cholesterol level is responsible for:

  • Maintaining cell membrane integrity and fluidity for every cell in your body. If cholesterol levels increase, cell membranes become more stiff and the flow of water and minerals like calcium, magnesium, sodium and potassium into and out of the cell is disrupted.
  • Cholesterol is also your body's building block to make bile acids. These are important for digestion and absorption of dietary fats, and the fat-soluble vitamins A, D, E, and K. Bile acids also regulate energy and help to maintain blood sugar balance.

Given your body's necessity for cholesterol, your liver and intestines work together to ensure a consistent, stable supply of it.

The excellent news is that your cholesterol level is optimal. Maintaining this optimal cholesterol level reduces your risk for cardiovascular diseases like heart attacks and stroke, as well as reducing your risk for gallstones.

It is worth noting that HRT (Hormone Replacement Therapy used commonly during menopause) can cause an increase in cholesterol so it is important to periodically check your levels when taking HRT.

If your cholesterol has changed, it has likely improved - and even though it is currently optimal, it is recommended to have your cholesterol checked regularly (every 2-3 years).
optimal.treatment:
You can help to keep your cholesterol at this ideal level by:

  • Eating a healthy, whole foods, high fiber diet. Reducing dietary cholesterol and fats usually has little to no impact on total cholesterol readings - but by limiting foods high in carbohydrates (refined sugars, starches and hydrogenated fats such as fried foods, margarine, coffee creamers, shortening etc) you can positively impact your cholesterol and therefore cardiovascular health.
  • Exercising regularly - 3-4 times/week.
  • Managing your stress by using methods like yoga, meditation and journaling
  • Cut down on / eliminate detrimental lifestyle habits such as smoking, excessive drinking or recreational drugs.

tests.name: Triglycerides
tests.description: Triglycerides are the most abundant type of fat (lipid) naturally found in food and the human body. When you eat food, your body converts unwanted calories into triglycerides.  These triglycerides are stored in the body to be used at a later time for a source of energy.

optimal.significance:
Triglycerides are the most abundant type of fat (lipid) naturally found in food and the human body. They are part of the lipid family of molecules carried in the bloodstream. When you eat foods, your body converts unwanted calories into triglycerides.  These triglycerides are stored in the body to be used at a later time for a source of energy.

Congrats - triglycerides in this reference range are considered to be optimal!  It appears that your liver is working well by not converting excess calories into triglycerides. Your age, your dietary habits and your lifestyle choices are contributing to this healthy result. As a woman, it is very important to address all aspects of cardiovascular health - diseases of the heart and circulatory systems can be a real risk for women of all ages, so keeping preventive measures in mind for a healthy heart is incredibly important!

What does this all mean?

Serum triglycerides reflect the body's regulatory capacity and are associated with blood sugar balance in conjunction with your diet. As an isolated marker of health, triglycerides don't provide the full picture so it's best to assess them alongside other tests including total cholesterol, HDL and LDL. Triglyceride health can be related to thyroid, adrenal and of course cardiovascular health so while it doesn't tell us much on its own, it's an extremely important piece of the puzzle. Triglycerides, along with cholesterol, have been shown to be closely connected to the thyroid, especially if TSH is increased. Not surprisingly, stress also impacts triglycerides: substances called catecholamines, which are released from the adrenal glands when we are stressed out, can cause an increased release of fatty acids into the blood stream, affecting both triglycerides and cholesterol.

Therefore, cross referencing with liver enzymes and thyroid blood tests should be considered as some conditions like hyperthyroidism (overactive thyroid), malabsorption syndrome (conditions in which the small intestine does not absorb fats well) and malnutrition can be linked with very low triglycerides.  In these cases it is best to discuss this with your healthcare practitioner.
optimal.treatment:
What's Next?

Since there is a significant correlation with the amount of triglycerides in your bloodstream and conditions like diabetes and heart disease, your diet and lifestyle have the biggest impact on triglyceride levels.  We know that the body needs food to produce fuel, and some of this fuel is needed in an instant while excess is stored for a later time.  The key is what food are used for this fuel and it is converted and stored in the body:

  1. Whole foods, particularly the ones that have a high fat content, like natural occurring oils from olives or avocados, nuts and seeds, lean grass-fed red meats and cold water fish are best to keep your triglycerides in check. Studies have shown that diets high in carbohydrates, hydrogenated fats, dairy and alcohol can greatly impact your triglycerides. Similar research points to the addition of healthy fiber in addition to healthy fats to support proper metabolism of triglycerides.

  1. Another key factor is physical activity.  Because triglyceride clearance is accomplished by both the liver and muscle tissue, and effective way of maintaining healthy triglyceride levels is to increase the muscle demand for energy with cardiovascular exercise and/or resistance training. Keeping active releases the excess stored fuel, which helps not to have the triglycerides accumulate in the body.  A balance of inputting your calories to outputting them through exercise maintains good health and slows down the progression of overall chronic disease formation. Whether you are playing organized sports, swimming, biking, walking or hiking, keep up with what you are doing.  Your body is loving it and it will keep your heart ticking for a long time.

Therefore, cross referencing with liver enzymes and thyroid blood tests should be considered as some conditions like hypo or hyperthyroidism, malabsorption syndrome (conditions in which the small intestine does not absorb fats well, like IBS, Crohn's or Ulcerative Colitis) and malnutrition can be linked with very low triglycerides.  In these cases it is best to discuss this with your healthcare practitioner.
tooLow.treatment:
What's Next?

Since there is a significant correlation with the amount of triglycerides in your bloodstream and conditions like diabetes and heart disease, your diet and lifestyle have the biggest impact on triglyceride levels.  We know that the body needs food to produce fuel, and some of this fuel is needed in an instant while excess is stored for a later time.  The key is what foods are used for this fuel and it is converted and stored in the body:

  1. Whole foods, particularly the ones that have a high fat content, like natural occurring oils from olives or avocados, nuts and seeds, lean grass-fed red meats and cold water fish are best to keep your triglycerides in a healthy balance. Studies have shown that diets high in carbohydrates, hydrogenated fats, dairy and alcohol can greatly impact your triglycerides. Similar research points to the addition of healthy fiber in addition to healthy fats to support proper metabolism of triglycerides. In fact, not having enough animal protein (ie: a vegetarian diet that doesn’t include enough healthy fats) can be enough to cause a slight dip in triglyceride levels.

  1. Another key factor is physical activity.  Because triglyceride clearance is accomplished by both the liver and muscle tissue, and effective way of maintaining healthy triglyceride levels is to increase the muscle demand for energy with cardiovascular exercise and/or resistance training. Keeping active releases the excess stored fuel, which helps not to have the triglycerides accumulate in the body.  A balance of inputting your calories to outputting them through exercise maintains good health and slows down the progression of overall chronic disease formation. Whether you are playing organized sports, swimming, biking, walking or hiking, keep up with what you are doing.  Your body is loving it and it will keep your heart ticking for a long time.

tooHigh.significance:
Triglycerides are the most abundant type of fat (lipid) naturally found in food and the human body. They are part of the lipid family of molecules carried in the bloodstream. When you eat foods, your body converts unwanted calories into triglycerides.  These triglycerides are stored in the body to be used at a later time for a source of energy.

Your triglyceride values are considered to be above normal in this range.  Therefore, there is room for improvement, particularly if there is a family history of heart diseases and diabetes.  If this is part of your first screening for lipid values, then consider this as a possible baseline result (soemthing to compare future tests to). Consult with your healthcare practitioner on when to retest.  If these current values of triglycerides are consistent, then looking at the possible causes of slightly elevated values may be a good idea. Your dietary habits and amount of physical activity are key to improving these satisfactory values.

What does this all mean?

Serum triglycerides reflect the body's regulatory capacity and are associated with blood sugar balance in conjunction with your diet. As an isolated marker of health, triglycerides don't provide the full picture so it's best to assess them alongside other tests including total cholesterol, HDL and LDL. Triglyceride health can be related to thyroid, adrenal and of course cardiovascular health so while it doesn't tell us much on its own, it's an extremely important piece of the puzzle. Triglycerides, along with cholesterol, have been shown to be closely connected to the thyroid, especially if TSH is increased. Not surprisingly, stress also impacts triglycerides: substances called catecholamines, which are released from the adrenal glands when we are stressed out, can cause an increased release of fatty acids into the blood stream, affecting both triglycerides and cholesterol.

Recent weight gain, stress, change in sleep or eating habits and lack of physical activity may be the causes of this mild increase in your triglycerides.  In addition, you may want to discuss any medications you may be taking with healthcare practitioner - medications like birth control, and/or steroids may be impacting your triglyceride levels.
tooHigh.treatment:
What's Next?

Since there is a significant correlation with the amount of triglycerides in your bloodstream and conditions like diabetes and heart disease, your diet and lifestyle have the biggest impact on triglyceride levels.  We know that the body needs food to produce fuel, and some of this fuel is needed in an instant while excess is stored for a later time.  The key is what foods are used for this fuel and how it is converted and stored in the body:

  1. Whole foods, particularly the ones that have a high fat content, like natural occurring oils from olives or avocados, nuts and seeds, lean grass-fed red meats and cold water fish are best to keep your triglycerides in check. Additionally, foods high in fiber like fruit, green veggies, nuts & protein-rich grains like quinoa may help to metabolize unncecssary triglycerides, as well as cholesterol.
  2. Diets high in processed carbohydrates and indulging in high caloric beverages like sodas and alcohol are contributing factors. Reducing these foods and beverages will benefit your triglycerides levels as well as future prevention of developing diabetes and heart disease.  In addition making sure that metabolic syndrome does not set in.

  1. Another key factor is physical activity.  Because triglyceride clearance is accomplished by both the liver and muscle tissue, and effective way of maintaining healthy triglyceride levels is to increase the muscle demand for energy with cardiovascular exercise and/or resistance training. Keeping active releases the excess stored fuel, which helps not to have the triglycerides accumulate in the body.  A balance of inputting your calories to outputting them through exercise maintains good health and slows down the progression of chronic disease formation. Whether you are playing organized sports, swimming, biking, walking or hiking, keep up with what you are doing.  Your body is loving it and it will keep your heart ticking for a long time.
  2. Talk to your healthcare provider about what next step needs to be taken to avoid chronic conditions like heart disease and diabetes.  In the meantime, think about maintaining optimal body weight, monitor your sugar intake, follow a lower refined carb diet, eat more fiber, eat more cold water fish, increase your intake of unsaturated fats, avoid trans fats and of course exercise regularly.
  3. Lastly look at your current stress levels.  Studies suggest that the high levels of cortisol from long-term stress can increase blood cholesterol, triglycerides, blood sugar, and blood pressure. Discuss with your healthcare practitioner as this being a possible reason for this mild spike in your triglyceride values.

tooLow.significance:

At this level, it’s not likely due to liver or biliary problem but those organs are related to triglyceride synthesis so further tests are a good idea. tooHigh.significance:
Triglycerides are the most abundant type of fat (lipid) naturally found in food and the human body. They are part of the lipid family of molecules carried in the bloodstream. When you eat foods, your body converts unwanted calories into triglycerides.  These triglycerides are stored in the body to be used at a later time for a source of energy.  Obesity and lack of regular exercise may be contributing factors to triglyceride values. 


Triglycerides in this reference range are high, considered very significant and will can have a negative impact on your health overall.  You need to discuss with your healthcare practitioner on what the next step will be on how to lower these values and how to reassess in the next few months.  Keeping these triglyceride values are a risk factor to developing chronic conditions. 

What does this all mean?

High triglycerides (hypertriglyceridemia) may contribute to hardening of the arteries or thickening of the artery walls (arteriosclerosis).  This increases the risk of heart attack, stroke and heart disease (cardiovascular disease). Extremely high triglycerides can cause pancreatitis, which is acute inflammation of the pancreas. Diabetes, obesity, and low levels of thyroid hormones (hypothyroidism), can also develop with hypertriglyceridemia. Lastly Metabolic syndrome, which is a cluster of conditions that includes too much fat around the waist, high blood pressure, high triglycerides, high blood sugar and abnormal cholesterol levels can develop and increase risk of heart disease  Let us not forget that rare genetic conditions that affect how your body converts fat to energy like familial hypertriglyceridemia , can be the cause of high triglycerides in the bloodstream.

Recent weight gain, stress, change in sleep or eating habits and lack of physical activity may be the causes of this mild increase in your triglycerides.  In addition keep in mind and discuss with your healthcare practitioner if your medication like birth control, and steroids are elevating your triglyceride levels.

optimal.significance:

Congrats - triglycerides in this reference range are considered to be optimal! It appears that your liver is working well by not converting excess calories into triglycerides. Your age, your dietary habits and your lifestyle choices are contributing to this healthy result. As a woman, it is very important to address all aspects of cardiovascular health - diseases of the heart and circulatory systems can be a real risk for women of all ages, but especially as we age, so keeping preventive measures in mind for a healthy heart is incredibly important!

What does this all mean?

As an isolated marker of health, triglycerides don't provide the full picture so it's best to assess them alongside other tests including total cholesterol, HDL and LDL. Not surprisingly, stress also impacts triglycerides: substances called catecholamines, which are released from the adrenal glands when we are stressed out, can cause an increased release of fatty acids into the blood stream, affecting both triglycerides and cholesterol.

Because stress can so insidiously impact many functions and organs in the body, including those controlling hormones (even those responsible for regulating menstrual cycles and even the way menopause is experienced!), it is incredibly important to integrate all tests results, along with physical and/or mental emotional symptoms in order to properly assess your overall health.

Triglycerides are the most abundant type of fat (lipid) naturally found in food and the human body. They are part of the lipid family of molecules carried in the bloodstream. When you eat foods, your body converts unwanted calories into triglycerides.  These triglycerides are stored in the body to be used at a later time for a source of energy.

Your triglycerides in this reference range are considered to below normal. As a woman, it is very important to address all aspects of cardiovascular health - diseases of the heart and circulatory systems can be a real risk for women of all ages, so keeping preventive measures in mind for a healthy heart is incredibly important! What could potentially contribute to low triglycerides? At this level, it’s not likely due to liver or biliary dysfunction but those organs are related to triglyceride synthesis so further tests are warranted. Some autoimmune disease can present with low triglycerides, low or normal total cholesterol and slightly elevated HDL cholesterol. This can indicate inflammation – so exploring C-reactive protein, ANA, rheumatoid factor etc). Some drugs that may impact triglycerides include nicotinic acid, clofibrate and gemfibrizol. Heavy metals or an excess of endurance exercise may also lead to a low triglyceride reading.

What does this all mean?

Serum triglycerides reflect the body's regulatory capacity and are associated with blood sugar balance in conjunction with your diet. As an isolated marker of health, triglycerides don't provide the full picture so it's best to assess them alongside other tests including total cholesterol, HDL and LDL. Triglyceride health can be related to thyroid, adrenal and of course cardiovascular health so while it doesn't tell us much on its own, it's an extremely important piece of the puzzle. Triglycerides, along with cholesterol, have been shown to be closely connected to the thyroid, especially if TSH is increased. Not surprisingly, stress also impacts triglycerides: substances called catecholamines, which are released from the adrenal glands when we are stressed out, can cause an increased release of fatty acids into the blood stream, affecting both triglycerides and cholesterol.

Therefore, as mentioned, cross referencing with liver enzymes and thyroid blood tests should be considered as some conditions like hypo/hyperthyroidism, malabsorption syndrome (conditions in which the small intestine does not absorb fats well such as SIBO, IBS, Crohn's or Ulcerative Colitis) and malnutrition can be linked with very low triglycerides.  In these cases it is best to discuss this with your healthcare practitioner.
tooLow.treatment:
What's Next?

Since there is a significant correlation with the amount of triglycerides in your bloodstream and conditions like diabetes and heart disease, your diet and lifestyle have the biggest impact on triglyceride levels.  We know that the body needs food to produce fuel, and some of this fuel is needed in an instant while excess is stored for a later time.  The key is what foods are used for this fuel and it is converted and stored in the body:

  1. Whole foods, particularly the ones that have a high fat content, like natural occurring oils from olives or avocados, nuts and seeds, lean grass-fed red meats and cold water fish are best to keep your triglycerides in a healthy balance.. Studies have shown that diets high in carbohydrates, hydrogenated fats, dairy and alcohol can greatly impact your triglycerides.
  2. Similar research points to the addition of healthy fiber in addition to healthy fats to support proper metabolism of triglycerides. In fact, not having enough animal protein (ie: a vegetarian diet that doesn’t include enough healthy fats) can be enough to cause a decline in triglyceride levels. Just more evidence to support the fact that what we eat is incredible important!

  1. Another key factor is physical activity.  Because triglyceride clearance is accomplished by both the liver and muscle tissue, and effective way of maintaining healthy triglyceride levels is to increase the muscle demand for energy with cardiovascular exercise and/or resistance training. Keeping active releases the excess stored fuel, which helps not to have the triglycerides accumulate in the body.  A balance of inputting your calories to outputting them through exercise maintains good health and slows down the progression of overall chronic disease formation. Whether you are playing organized sports, swimming, biking, walking or hiking, keep up with what you are doing.  Your body is loving it and it will keep your heart ticking for a long time.

tooHigh.significance:
Triglycerides are the most abundant type of fat (lipid) naturally found in food and the human body. They are part of the lipid family of molecules carried in the bloodstream. When you eat foods, your body converts unwanted calories into triglycerides.  These triglycerides are stored in the body to be used at a later time for a source of energy.  Obesity and lack of regular exercise may be contributing factors to triglyceride values.  Your age can also contribute to the increase.

Triglycerides in this reference range are high, considered very significant and can have a negative impact on your health overall.  You need to discuss with your healthcare practitioner on what the next step will be on how to lower these values and how to reassess in the next few months.  While this result is not diagnostic on its own, if these triglyceride values are maintained, it could pose a risk factor to developing a number of chronic conditions in the future.

What does this all mean?

High triglycerides (hypertriglyceridemia) may contribute to hardening of the arteries or thickening of the artery walls (arteriosclerosis).  This increases the risk of heart attack, stroke and heart disease (cardiovascular disease). Extremely high triglycerides can cause pancreatitis, which is acute inflammation of the pancreas. Diabetes, obesity, and low levels of thyroid hormones (hypothyroidism), can also develop with hypertriglyceridemia. Lastly Metabolic syndrome, which is a cluster of conditions that includes too much fat around the waist, high blood pressure, high triglycerides, high blood sugar and abnormal cholesterol levels can develop and increase risk of heart disease. Let us not forget that rare genetic conditions that affect how your body converts fat to energy like familial hypertriglyceridemia, which can be the cause of high triglycerides in the bloodstream.

Lastly look at your current stress levels.  Studies suggest that the high levels of cortisol from long-term stress can increase blood cholesterol, triglycerides, blood sugar, and blood pressure. Discuss with your healthcare practitioner as this being a possible reason for the spike in your triglyceride values.

Keep in mind that medications like hormone replacement, birth control, steroids and diuretics can elevate triglyceride values.  Hormone changes especially as women approach the age of 50, can contribute to increasing triglycerides. Additionally, Have your hormones assessed as well. Perimenopause, menopause and hormone replacement can reflect changes in triglycerides.
tooHigh.treatment:
What’s Next?

Since there is a significant correlation with the amount of triglycerides in your bloodstream and conditions like diabetes and heart disease, your diet and lifestyle have the biggest impact on triglyceride levels. We know that the body needs food to produce fuel, and some of this fuel is needed in an instant while excess is stored for a later time. The key is what foods are used for this fuel and how it is converted and stored in the body:

  1. Whole foods, particularly the ones that have a high fat content, like natural occurring oils from olives or avocados, nuts and seeds, lean grass-fed red meats and cold water fish are best to keep your triglycerides in check. Additionally, foods high in fiber like fruit, green veggies, nuts & protein-rich grains like quinoa will help to metabolize unnecessary triglycerides, as well as cholesterol.
  2. Diets high in processed carbohydrates and indulging in high caloric beverages like sodas and alcohol are contributing factors. Reducing these foods and beverages will benefit your triglycerides levels as well as future prevention of developing diabetes and heart disease.  In addition making sure that metabolic syndrome does not set in.

  1. Another key factor is physical activity.  Because triglyceride clearance is accomplished by both the liver and muscle tissue, and effective way of maintaining healthy triglyceride levels is to increase the muscle demand for energy with cardiovascular exercise and/or resistance training. Keeping active releases the excess stored fuel, which helps not to have the triglycerides accumulate in the body.  A balance of inputting your calories to outputting them through exercise maintains good health and slows down the progression of chronic disease formation. Whether you are playing organized sports, swimming, biking, walking or hiking, keep up with what you are doing.  Your body is loving it and it will keep your heart ticking for a long time.
  2. Talk to your healthcare provider about what next step needs to be taken to avoid chronic conditions like heart disease and diabetes.  In the meantime, think about maintaining optimal body weight, monitor your sugar intake, follow a lower refined carb diet, eat more fiber, eat more cold water fish, increase your intake of unsaturated fats, avoid trans fats and of course exercise regularly.
  3. Lastly look at your current stress levels.  Studies suggest that the high levels of cortisol from long-term stress can increase blood cholesterol, triglycerides, blood sugar, and blood pressure. Discuss with your healthcare practitioner as this being a possible reason for this spike in your triglyceride values.
